issue.title: Add allowDisableSeccomp to bugmon-monitor
issue.body: This is required for running pernosco-submit on the bugmon reporter instances.

comment.body:
We recently removed the disableSeccomp support, as there were no current use cases, and the unit tests were invalid. I would propose we solve this by moving to generic-worker, since this will be a requirement next year anyway.

We are happy to work with you to migrate the tasks, we've already had some success migrating real world decision tasks from firefox-ci. Our recommended approach is to call docker (or podman) as a task command, if it is preferred to run the task inside a container, or to just run natively on the host environment if a container isn't required. Both should work, and provide the freedom to customise the command line options of docker/podman to enable the specific features you require (in this case, allow you to run e.g. `docker run --security-opt seccomp=unconfined ...` as a command in your task payload). We prefer podman over docker, where possible, since with podman, you can be an unprivileged user on the host, but be root in the container (whereas with docker, the host user needs to be in the `docker` group).

issue.title: Require hashes on objects
issue.body:
Let's set some kind of enforced minimum of hashes for an object upload to be accepted, which downloaders can then expect to find.

For the moment, we define `sha256` and `sha512`, but don't say anything about when they must be defined.  Over the years, we'll probably want to add hash algorithms, and eventually older hash algorithms will be deprecated (as md5 and sha1 have been), so we should have a policy that allows some kind of evolution.  Perhaps:

 * must include at least one of [algos still considered secure] (e.g., sha256, sha512)
 * should include [most secure algo] (e.g., sha512)
 * can also include [deprecated algos] (e.g., md5, sha1)

Downloaders should be expected to verify all recognized algorithms for which there are hashes, and to verify that at least one of the first set are present.

This gives enough time for some evolution: assuming sha1024 is the next best algorithm, uploaders can start adding it but also including sha256 and sha512.  During that time, downloaders will validate sha256 and sha512, and new implementations will also validate sha1024.  Then by the time sha256 is deprecated, uploaders and downloaders will already be using sha512 and sha1024, and can drop sha256.

I think this would be a docs-only fix, for now.

Thoughts?

pull_request.title: Issue 5836 - build start-worker-windows-386
pull_request.body:
Github Bug/Issue: Fixes #5836

There were two problems:

1) The bash script `tools/worker-runner/build.sh` that builds Worker Runner executables (executable `start-worker-*`) was not configured to exit in case of a failure (`set -e`).
2) Code inside worker-runner attempted to detect an overflow condition and trigger a runtime panic if it found one. This did not work, did not compile for 32 bit platforms, and also added no value - the go runtime itself would detect such an overflow and trigger a runtime exception. And the runtime exception would probably provide better information than this customised version.

pull_request.title: Hook last fires pagination
pull_request.body:
This PR changes:
- `get_last_fires` uses sorting by creation date to avoid doing full scan to find latest
- `hooks_last_fires` table has new index to allow faster ORDER BY + LIMIT queries for time column
- changes graphql that adds pagination to `lastHookFires` to avoid sending everything to the client

Closes: #5804 #5573 #4870

issue.title: Generic worker test failures difficult to find
issue.body:
When generic-worker tests fail in the CI, the failure text is often not at the end of the log, but at the point the test occurred, which can make it harder for people not familiar with this, to find the failures. It might (?) be nicer if we specify `-failfast` when running generic-worker tests so that tasks stop as soon as they hit a failure.

Note, an alternative would be to log a message after the failure saying something like "Please be aware you should search for `FAIL:` in the output above to find the source of the test failure" but that might be making things too complicated.

An advantage of running all tests is that you don't just tackle failures one-by-one, but get all the failure information in one shot. But maybe this is outweighed by the benefits of saving resources in CI and having the failure at the bottom of the log.

Another option to consider at this time is removing "verbose" output in the logs (`go test -v`). Passing tests should produce no output. Sometimes the verbose output is useful to compare succeeding and failing tasks, but probably this is more the exception than the rule.

comment.body: Fixed by #5782 and #5827.

issue.title: disableSeccomp CI test failing
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
We are hitting the following permafail in taskcluster CI for docker-worker-chunk-2 tasks:

```
  26 passing (2m)
  1 pending
  1 failing

  1) disableSeccomp capability
       use performance counter in a container with disableSeccomp -- task should succeed:

      AssertionError [ERR_ASSERTION]: task should not fail
      + expected - actual

      -false
      +true
      
      at Context.<anonymous> (test/integration/disable_seccomp_containers_test.js:112:5)
      at processTicksAndRejections (node:internal/process/task_queues:96:5)



[taskcluster 2022-11-28 14:53:19.466Z] === Task Finished ===
```

From [this manually crafted task](https://community-tc.services.mozilla.com/tasks/KVt31Cu_TXGocWO6yshomQ/runs/0) we can see that the disableSeccomp capability [works](https://serverfault.com/questions/929589/docker-check-if-default-seccomp-profile-is-applied) as intended. However, the test seems not to work properly.

comment.body: Fixed with the removal of the feature

issue.title: Generate generic worker schemas to avoid information redundancy.
issue.body:
There are schemas here:

```
workers/generic-worker/schemas/docker_posix.yml
workers/generic-worker/schemas/multiuser_posix.yml
workers/generic-worker/schemas/multiuser_windows.yml
workers/generic-worker/schemas/simple_posix.yml
```

1. These contain a lot of redundancy, so if we are going to keep multiple engines, we should auto generate common content here, or reference an external schema, etc.
2. These schemas contain a list of file extensions which is taken from code. It is likely that at some point the docs and code will get out of sync. This was highlighted by PR #5825. Let's make sure this list is defined in once place only.

issue.title: Generic worker test failures difficult to find
issue.body:
When generic-worker tests fail in the CI, the failure text is often not at the end of the log, but at the point the test occurred, which can make it harder for people not familiar with this, to find the failures. It might (?) be nicer if we specify `-failfast` when running generic-worker tests so that tasks stop as soon as they hit a failure.

Note, an alternative would be to log a message after the failure saying something like "Please be aware you should search for `FAIL:` in the output above to find the source of the test failure" but that might be making things too complicated.

An advantage of running all tests is that you don't just tackle failures one-by-one, but get all the failure information in one shot. But maybe this is outweighed by the benefits of saving resources in CI and having the failure at the bottom of the log.

Another option to consider at this time is removing "verbose" output in the logs (`go test -v`). Passing tests should produce no output. Sometimes the verbose output is useful to compare succeeding and failing tasks, but probably this is more the exception than the rule.

comment.body:
Looks like #5782 was not enough to resolve this issue. See e.g. https://community-tc.services.mozilla.com/tasks/M8Q49_00Qy-7Ro0fTUdv3A/runs/0/logs/live/public/logs/live.log

It seems that `go test` and `go test .` [operate differently](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/31663229/how-can-stdout-be-captured-or-suppressed-for-golang-testing) in this regard, and `go test` needs to be replaced with `go test .` to suppress the output.

issue.body: This is required for running pernosco-submit on the bugmon reporter instances.

comment.body:
We recently removed the disableSeccomp support, as there were no current use cases, and the unit tests were invalid. I would propose we solve this by moving to generic-worker, since this will be a requirement next year anyway.

We are happy to work with you to migrate the tasks, we've already had some success migrating real world decision tasks from firefox-ci. Our recommended approach is to call docker (or podman) as a task command, if it is preferred to run the task inside a container, or to just run natively on the host environment if a container isn't required. Both should work, and provide the freedom to customise the command line options of docker/podman to enable the specific features you require (in this case, allow you to run e.g. `docker run --security-opt seccomp=unconfined ...` as a command in your task payload). We prefer podman over docker, where possible, since with podman, you can be an unprivileged user on the host, but be root in the container (whereas with docker, the host user needs to be in the `docker` group).

issue.title: Require hashes on objects
issue.body:
Let's set some kind of enforced minimum of hashes for an object upload to be accepted, which downloaders can then expect to find.

For the moment, we define `sha256` and `sha512`, but don't say anything about when they must be defined.  Over the years, we'll probably want to add hash algorithms, and eventually older hash algorithms will be deprecated (as md5 and sha1 have been), so we should have a policy that allows some kind of evolution.  Perhaps:

 * must include at least one of [algos still considered secure] (e.g., sha256, sha512)
 * should include [most secure algo] (e.g., sha512)
 * can also include [deprecated algos] (e.g., md5, sha1)

Downloaders should be expected to verify all recognized algorithms for which there are hashes, and to verify that at least one of the first set are present.

This gives enough time for some evolution: assuming sha1024 is the next best algorithm, uploaders can start adding it but also including sha256 and sha512.  During that time, downloaders will validate sha256 and sha512, and new implementations will also validate sha1024.  Then by the time sha256 is deprecated, uploaders and downloaders will already be using sha512 and sha1024, and can drop sha256.

I think this would be a docs-only fix, for now.

Thoughts?

pull_request.title: Issue 5836 - build start-worker-windows-386
pull_request.body:
Github Bug/Issue: Fixes #5836

There were two problems:

1) The bash script `tools/worker-runner/build.sh` that builds Worker Runner executables (executable `start-worker-*`) was not configured to exit in case of a failure (`set -e`).
2) Code inside worker-runner attempted to detect an overflow condition and trigger a runtime panic if it found one. This did not work, did not compile for 32 bit platforms, and also added no value - the go runtime itself would detect such an overflow and trigger a runtime exception. And the runtime exception would probably provide better information than this customised version.

pull_request.title: Hook last fires pagination
pull_request.body:
This PR changes:
- `get_last_fires` uses sorting by creation date to avoid doing full scan to find latest
- `hooks_last_fires` table has new index to allow faster ORDER BY + LIMIT queries for time column
- changes graphql that adds pagination to `lastHookFires` to avoid sending everything to the client

Closes: #5804 #5573 #4870

issue.title: Generic worker test failures difficult to find
issue.body:
When generic-worker tests fail in the CI, the failure text is often not at the end of the log, but at the point the test occurred, which can make it harder for people not familiar with this, to find the failures. It might (?) be nicer if we specify `-failfast` when running generic-worker tests so that tasks stop as soon as they hit a failure.

Note, an alternative would be to log a message after the failure saying something like "Please be aware you should search for `FAIL:` in the output above to find the source of the test failure" but that might be making things too complicated.

An advantage of running all tests is that you don't just tackle failures one-by-one, but get all the failure information in one shot. But maybe this is outweighed by the benefits of saving resources in CI and having the failure at the bottom of the log.

Another option to consider at this time is removing "verbose" output in the logs (`go test -v`). Passing tests should produce no output. Sometimes the verbose output is useful to compare succeeding and failing tasks, but probably this is more the exception than the rule.

comment.body: Fixed by #5782 and #5827.

issue.title: disableSeccomp CI test failing
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
We are hitting the following permafail in taskcluster CI for docker-worker-chunk-2 tasks:

```
  26 passing (2m)
  1 pending
  1 failing

  1) disableSeccomp capability
       use performance counter in a container with disableSeccomp -- task should succeed:

      AssertionError [ERR_ASSERTION]: task should not fail
      + expected - actual

      -false
      +true
      
      at Context.<anonymous> (test/integration/disable_seccomp_containers_test.js:112:5)
      at processTicksAndRejections (node:internal/process/task_queues:96:5)



[taskcluster 2022-11-28 14:53:19.466Z] === Task Finished ===
```

From [this manually crafted task](https://community-tc.services.mozilla.com/tasks/KVt31Cu_TXGocWO6yshomQ/runs/0) we can see that the disableSeccomp capability [works](https://serverfault.com/questions/929589/docker-check-if-default-seccomp-profile-is-applied) as intended. However, the test seems not to work properly.

comment.body: Fixed with the removal of the feature

issue.title: Generate generic worker schemas to avoid information redundancy.
issue.body:
There are schemas here:

```
workers/generic-worker/schemas/docker_posix.yml
workers/generic-worker/schemas/multiuser_posix.yml
workers/generic-worker/schemas/multiuser_windows.yml
workers/generic-worker/schemas/simple_posix.yml
```

1. These contain a lot of redundancy, so if we are going to keep multiple engines, we should auto generate common content here, or reference an external schema, etc.
2. These schemas contain a list of file extensions which is taken from code. It is likely that at some point the docs and code will get out of sync. This was highlighted by PR #5825. Let's make sure this list is defined in once place only.

issue.title: Generic worker test failures difficult to find
issue.body:
When generic-worker tests fail in the CI, the failure text is often not at the end of the log, but at the point the test occurred, which can make it harder for people not familiar with this, to find the failures. It might (?) be nicer if we specify `-failfast` when running generic-worker tests so that tasks stop as soon as they hit a failure.

Note, an alternative would be to log a message after the failure saying something like "Please be aware you should search for `FAIL:` in the output above to find the source of the test failure" but that might be making things too complicated.

An advantage of running all tests is that you don't just tackle failures one-by-one, but get all the failure information in one shot. But maybe this is outweighed by the benefits of saving resources in CI and having the failure at the bottom of the log.

Another option to consider at this time is removing "verbose" output in the logs (`go test -v`). Passing tests should produce no output. Sometimes the verbose output is useful to compare succeeding and failing tasks, but probably this is more the exception than the rule.

comment.body:
Looks like #5782 was not enough to resolve this issue. See e.g. https://community-tc.services.mozilla.com/tasks/M8Q49_00Qy-7Ro0fTUdv3A/runs/0/logs/live/public/logs/live.log

It seems that `go test` and `go test .` [operate differently](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/31663229/how-can-stdout-be-captured-or-suppressed-for-golang-testing) in this regard, and `go test` needs to be replaced with `go test .` to suppress the output.

issue.title: Add allowDisableSeccomp to bugmon-monitor
issue.body: This is required for running pernosco-submit on the bugmon reporter instances.

comment.body:
We recently removed the disableSeccomp support, as there were no current use cases, and the unit tests were invalid. I would propose we solve this by moving to generic-worker, since this will be a requirement next year anyway.

We are happy to work with you to migrate the tasks, we've already had some success migrating real world decision tasks from firefox-ci. Our recommended approach is to call docker (or podman) as a task command, if it is preferred to run the task inside a container, or to just run natively on the host environment if a container isn't required. Both should work, and provide the freedom to customise the command line options of docker/podman to enable the specific features you require (in this case, allow you to run e.g. `docker run --security-opt seccomp=unconfined ...` as a command in your task payload). We prefer podman over docker, where possible, since with podman, you can be an unprivileged user on the host, but be root in the container (whereas with docker, the host user needs to be in the `docker` group).

issue.title: Require hashes on objects
issue.body:
Let's set some kind of enforced minimum of hashes for an object upload to be accepted, which downloaders can then expect to find.

For the moment, we define `sha256` and `sha512`, but don't say anything about when they must be defined.  Over the years, we'll probably want to add hash algorithms, and eventually older hash algorithms will be deprecated (as md5 and sha1 have been), so we should have a policy that allows some kind of evolution.  Perhaps:

 * must include at least one of [algos still considered secure] (e.g., sha256, sha512)
 * should include [most secure algo] (e.g., sha512)
 * can also include [deprecated algos] (e.g., md5, sha1)

Downloaders should be expected to verify all recognized algorithms for which there are hashes, and to verify that at least one of the first set are present.

This gives enough time for some evolution: assuming sha1024 is the next best algorithm, uploaders can start adding it but also including sha256 and sha512.  During that time, downloaders will validate sha256 and sha512, and new implementations will also validate sha1024.  Then by the time sha256 is deprecated, uploaders and downloaders will already be using sha512 and sha1024, and can drop sha256.

I think this would be a docs-only fix, for now.

Thoughts?

This adds some guidance in the form of comments, and also sets `additionalProperties: false`, for reasons outlined in those comments.

pull_request.title: Issue 5836 - build start-worker-windows-386
pull_request.body:
Github Bug/Issue: Fixes #5836

There were two problems:

1) The bash script `tools/worker-runner/build.sh` that builds Worker Runner executables (executable `start-worker-*`) was not configured to exit in case of a failure (`set -e`).
2) Code inside worker-runner attempted to detect an overflow condition and trigger a runtime panic if it found one. This did not work, did not compile for 32 bit platforms, and also added no value - the go runtime itself would detect such an overflow and trigger a runtime exception. And the runtime exception would probably provide better information than this customised version.

pull_request.title: Hook last fires pagination
pull_request.body:
This PR changes:
- `get_last_fires` uses sorting by creation date to avoid doing full scan to find latest
- `hooks_last_fires` table has new index to allow faster ORDER BY + LIMIT queries for time column
- changes graphql that adds pagination to `lastHookFires` to avoid sending everything to the client

Closes: #5804 #5573 #4870

issue.title: Generic worker test failures difficult to find
issue.body:
When generic-worker tests fail in the CI, the failure text is often not at the end of the log, but at the point the test occurred, which can make it harder for people not familiar with this, to find the failures. It might (?) be nicer if we specify `-failfast` when running generic-worker tests so that tasks stop as soon as they hit a failure.

Note, an alternative would be to log a message after the failure saying something like "Please be aware you should search for `FAIL:` in the output above to find the source of the test failure" but that might be making things too complicated.

An advantage of running all tests is that you don't just tackle failures one-by-one, but get all the failure information in one shot. But maybe this is outweighed by the benefits of saving resources in CI and having the failure at the bottom of the log.

Another option to consider at this time is removing "verbose" output in the logs (`go test -v`). Passing tests should produce no output. Sometimes the verbose output is useful to compare succeeding and failing tasks, but probably this is more the exception than the rule.

comment.body: Fixed by #5782 and #5827.

issue.title: disableSeccomp CI test failing
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
We are hitting the following permafail in taskcluster CI for docker-worker-chunk-2 tasks:

```
  26 passing (2m)
  1 pending
  1 failing

  1) disableSeccomp capability
       use performance counter in a container with disableSeccomp -- task should succeed:

      AssertionError [ERR_ASSERTION]: task should not fail
      + expected - actual

      -false
      +true
      
      at Context.<anonymous> (test/integration/disable_seccomp_containers_test.js:112:5)
      at processTicksAndRejections (node:internal/process/task_queues:96:5)



[taskcluster 2022-11-28 14:53:19.466Z] === Task Finished ===
```

From [this manually crafted task](https://community-tc.services.mozilla.com/tasks/KVt31Cu_TXGocWO6yshomQ/runs/0) we can see that the disableSeccomp capability [works](https://serverfault.com/questions/929589/docker-check-if-default-seccomp-profile-is-applied) as intended. However, the test seems not to work properly.

comment.body: Fixed with the removal of the feature

issue.title: Generate generic worker schemas to avoid information redundancy.
issue.body:
There are schemas here:

```
workers/generic-worker/schemas/docker_posix.yml
workers/generic-worker/schemas/multiuser_posix.yml
workers/generic-worker/schemas/multiuser_windows.yml
workers/generic-worker/schemas/simple_posix.yml
```

1. These contain a lot of redundancy, so if we are going to keep multiple engines, we should auto generate common content here, or reference an external schema, etc.
2. These schemas contain a list of file extensions which is taken from code. It is likely that at some point the docs and code will get out of sync. This was highlighted by PR #5825. Let's make sure this list is defined in once place only.

issue.title: Generic worker test failures difficult to find
issue.body:
When generic-worker tests fail in the CI, the failure text is often not at the end of the log, but at the point the test occurred, which can make it harder for people not familiar with this, to find the failures. It might (?) be nicer if we specify `-failfast` when running generic-worker tests so that tasks stop as soon as they hit a failure.

comment.body:
Looks like #5782 was not enough to resolve this issue. See e.g. https://community-tc.services.mozilla.com/tasks/M8Q49_00Qy-7Ro0fTUdv3A/runs/0/logs/live/public/logs/live.log

It seems that `go test` and `go test .` [operate differently](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/31663229/how-can-stdout-be-captured-or-suppressed-for-golang-testing) in this regard, and `go test` needs to be replaced with `go test .` to suppress the output.
